headline:
Tech companies have a trust gap to overcome—especially with women
					Women are more wary than men about how their personal data is used and protected—particularly sensitive health data—and that may prevent them from maximizing future tech benefits.
					Article6-MIN READ

<div>
    <div class="cmp-text ">
        <p> </p>
<p>Consumers are growing more concerned about being “hacked and tracked” through their tech devices. Our <a href="/us/en/insights/industry/telecommunications/connectivity-mobile-trends-survey.html">2023 Connected Consumer Survey</a> found that 58% of respondents worry that their devices are vulnerable to security breaches (for example, hackers stealing personal data), up 8 points from last year.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-1" href="#endnote-1">1</a></sup> The same number also worry that organizations or individuals could track their movements or behavior through their devices, up 17 points from last year.</p>
<p>These security fears appear justified: 2022 nearly tied the record set in 2021 for the most data breaches affecting US consumers.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-2" href="#endnote-2">2</a></sup> In our survey, 34% of respondents said they experienced at least one type of breach or scam in the past year, and 16% fell victim to two or more.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-3" href="#endnote-3">3</a></sup></p>
<p>But it’s not just hackers that consumers worry about: Consumer trust in the companies that sell devices, apps, and online services is eroding, too. Only 50% of respondents feel that the benefits they get from online services outweigh their data privacy concerns—a 9 point drop from 2021—and just 34% feel companies are clear about how they use the data they collect from users—a 14 point drop from 2021.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-4" href="#endnote-4">4</a></sup></p>

<div class="container responsivegrid content-width-di-sm aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
    
    
    
    <div id="container-8944826ee5" class="cmp-container">
        
        <div class="text cmp-di-text pt-1 mb-5 pl-mob-2 pr-mob-2 aem-GridColumn--phone--12 cmp-di-text--line-height-large">

    


<div>
    <div class="cmp-text ">
        <p>This lack of trust is more pronounced among women:<sup><a id="endnote-sup-5" href="#endnote-5">5</a></sup> They’re less convinced that the benefits they get from online services are worth the privacy risk, and more skeptical about how those services protect their data (figure 1). They also feel less informed about how their personal data is collected and used, as well as the steps they could take to limit or control that use. The trust gap appears to be affecting their willingness to share data, particularly when it comes to sensitive health and fitness metrics. In our survey, only 43% of women surveyed with smart watches or fitness trackers said that they share the data collected by those devices with their health care provider, versus 57% of men. They’re also less interested in participating in some near-future scenarios, such as having health metrics flow automatically from their wearables to a health care provider (43%, versus 52% of men) or having fitness metrics transmit automatically to a third party, such as a personal trainer (30%, versus 39% of men).</p>
<p>The disparities around willingness to share data could impact health inequities as use cases that rely on wearable data emerge and mature. There are pilots, for example, in which surgeons monitor their patients’ exercise before and after knee surgery via daily data feeds from smart watches.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-6" href="#endnote-6">6</a></sup> Some patients use wearables to monitor blood glucose levels and heart arrythmias, share results with their providers, and get more immediate insights.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-7" href="#endnote-7">7</a></sup> Data collected from wearables is allowing individuals to participate in large-scale research studies on respiratory, heart, neurological, and liver diseases, in addition to sleep quality, diabetes, and mental illness.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-8" href="#endnote-8">8</a></sup> As health care providers incorporate patient-generated data into their evaluations, potential benefits include earlier detection of issues and better quality of care. If some patient cohorts are less likely to share data and participate in these collaborations systemic health inequities could deepen.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-9" href="#endnote-9">9</a></sup></p>
<p>What’s behind this trust gap? It’s possible that women regard data collection and sharing as more risky than men do, and that they perceive the potential consequences of a security breach or data misuse as more significant.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-10" href="#endnote-10">10</a></sup> These fears may be warranted. Consider that most health apps—along with the data they gather and transmit—are not covered by the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA), which means the data may be shared or sold to third parties.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-11" href="#endnote-11">11</a></sup> Indeed, in an assessment of 23 women’s mobile health apps, researchers found that 20 of the apps shared data with third parties, while only 13 supplied users with information about data security.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-12" href="#endnote-12">12</a></sup> At least one women’s health app that tracks reproductive metrics has already come under fire for misleading users about how it shared sensitive data.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-13" href="#endnote-13">13</a></sup> More broadly, the digital trails that individuals leave—search and browser histories, location data, and so on—may be mined for potentially harmful purposes.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-14" href="#endnote-14">14</a></sup></p>
<p>It’s also possible that existing gender inequities in health care could be contributing to women’s hesitancy to share health data. FemTech, a relatively new category of health tech focused on building products, software, and services that support women’s health and wellness, has the potential to help address health inequities.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-15" href="#endnote-15">15</a></sup> However, FemTech providers should design their offerings with data privacy, security, and transparency from the start—or risk alienating the very consumers they are aiming to attract.</p>

    </div>
</div>

    

</div>

        
    </div>

</div>
<div class="container responsivegrid content-width-di-sm aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
    
    
    
    <div id="container-ffa46e41b8" class="cmp-container">
        
        <div class="text cmp-di-text pt-1 mb-5 pl-mob-2 pr-mob-2 aem-GridColumn--phone--12 cmp-di-text--line-height-large">

    


<div>
    <div class="cmp-text ">
        <h2>Considerations for tech companies</h2>
<p>To bridge the growing trust gap with consumers—and women, in particular—tech companies could give consumers more control and partner with them on how their data gets used. Some steps tech providers could take include:</p>
<ul><li>Enhancing data security measures on devices and for online services and making it easier for consumers to implement security measures.</li><li>Being more transparent about data-handling practices (e.g., what data they collect, how long they keep it, how they use it, how they protect it, and whether they share it with third parties.)</li><li>Disclosing whether and under what circumstances they’re obligated to share data with law enforcement and tailoring their data retention strategies to avoid keeping any sensitive information in-house.</li><li>Giving consumers more choice over how their data is used and with whom it’s shared, with easier ways to opt out or refine that use.</li><li>Giving consumers incentives to share data—for example, in the form of perks or loyalty programs.</li><li>Considering whether generative AI could be used in future products or services to tailor privacy and data sharing to suit each person’s comfort level.</li></ul>

    </div>
</div>

    

</div>

        
    </div>

</div>

<div class="cmp-di-endnotes__list">
         <ol> 
             <li><p>Jana Arbanas, Paul Silverglate, Susanne Hupfer, Jeff Loucks, Prashant Raman, and Michael Steinhart, <a href="https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/insights/industry/telecommunications/connectivity-mobile-trends-survey.html/"><i>Balancing act: Seeking just the right amount of digital for a happy, healthy connected life—The 2023 Connected consumer survey</i></a>, Deloitte Insights, September 7, 2023; Jana Arbanas, Paul Silverglate, Susanne Hupfer, Jeff Loucks, and Michael Steinhart, <a href="https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/insights/industry/telecommunications/connectivity-mobile-trends-survey.html?id=us:2el:3dp:wsjspon:awa:WSJCMO:2022:WSJFY23"><i>Mastering the new digital life: Connectivity and mobile trends study, 3rd edition</i></a>, Deloitte Insights, August 3, 2022.</p>
<a href="#endnote-sup-1" id="endnote-1">View in Article</a></li>
         
             <li><p>2021 set a record for total data breaches, but the incidents in 2022 impacted an even greater number of people. See: Bree Fowler, “<a href="https://www.cnet.com/tech/services-and-software/data-breaches-hit-lots-more-people-in-2022/">Data breaches hit lots more people in 2022</a>,” <i>CNET</i>, January 25, 2023; Bree Fowler, “<a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/privacy/record-number-of-data-breaches-reported-in-2021-new-report-says">Data breaches break record in 2021</a>,”<i>CNET</i>, January 24, 2022.</p>
<a href="#endnote-sup-2" id="endnote-2">View in Article</a></li>
         
             <li><p>The types of breaches we asked about were identity/credentials stolen, credit card hacked, bank account hacked, health data breached, ransomware/malware attack, falling for an online scam, social media account hacked, location information misused, and device hacked.</p>
<a href="#endnote-sup-3" id="endnote-3">View in Article</a></li>
         
             <li><p>Jana Arbanas, Paul Silvergate, Susanna Hupfer, Jeff Loucks, Prashat Raman, <a href="https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/insights/industry/telecommunications/connectivity-mobile-trends-survey.html#read-the-introduction"><i>Balancing act: Seeking just the right among of digital for a happy, healthy connected life</i></a>, 2023; Chris Arkenberg, Jeff Loucks, Paul Silverglate, and Jana Arbanas, <a href="https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/insights/industry/telecommunications/connectivity-mobile-trends-survey-2021.html"><i>2021 Connectivity and mobile trends survey: How the pandemic has stress-tested the crowded digital home</i></a>, Deloitte Insights, 2021.</p>
<a href="#endnote-sup-4" id="endnote-4">View in Article</a></li>
         
             <li><p>Our survey provided the following gender self-identification options for respondents to choose from: man, woman, non-binary, other, prefer not to answer. We have included here a comparison of those categories (i.e., man and woman) where we had a sufficient number of respondents to report.</p>
<a href="#endnote-sup-5" id="endnote-5">View in Article</a></li>
         
             <li><p>Denise Dador, "<a href="https://abc7.com/smart-watch-doctors-health-apple/13263162">Doctors tap the potential of smart watches, using them to monitor patients' health and progress</a>," <i>ABC7 News</i>, May 18, 2023.</p>
<a href="#endnote-sup-6" id="endnote-6">View in Article</a></li>
         
             <li><p>Lisa Buffington, “<a href="https://www.torrancememorial.org/healthy-living/blog/popular-wearables-support-cardiac-health/">Popular wearables support cardiac health</a>,” Torrance Memorial Good Health Blog, September 1, 2022.</p>
<a href="#endnote-sup-7" id="endnote-7">View in Article</a></li>
         
             <li><p>Linda Keslar, "<a href="https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/news/20230901/how-your-smartwatch-could-help-us-unlock-secrets-of-disease">How your smartwatch could help unlock secrets of disease</a>," <i>WebMD</i>, September 1, 2023.</p>
<a href="#endnote-sup-8" id="endnote-8">View in Article</a></li>
         
             <li><p>Despite making 80% of household health care decisions and spending more on health care than men, women are more likely to experience bias, such as health providers dismissing their symptoms or misdiagnosing them.  Women are underrepresented in clinical trials for drugs and devices, and just 4% of medical research focuses specifically on women’s health. Actuarial research also shows that employed women’s out-of-pocket medical costs are disproportionately higher than men’s. See: Kathryn Haines and Linda DaSilva, "<a href="https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/blog/health-care-blog/2023/an-economic-case-for-a-more-women-centric-health-care-system.html">An economic case for a more women-centric health care system</a>," Deloitte, July 27, 2023; Manisha Vadali, “<a href="https://hms.harvard.edu/news/more-data-needed">More data deeded: Study shows females underrepresented in key disease clinical trials</a>,” Brigham and Women's Communications, Harvard Medical School, June 29, 2022; Kulleni Gebreyes, Andy Davis, et al., "<a href="https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/pages/life-sciences-and-health-care/articles/womens-health-equity-disparities.html">Hiding in plain sight: The health care gender toll</a>," Deloitte, September 28, 2023; Sheryl Jacobson and Jen Radin,"<a href="https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/blog/health-care-blog/2023/can-femtech-help-bridge-a-gender-equity-gap-in-health-care.html">Can FemTech help bridge a gender-equity gap in health care?</a>," Deloitte, October 5, 2023; Karen Taylor, "<a href="https://blogs.deloitte.co.uk/health/2023/06/celebrating-the-nhs-at-75-why-investing-in-femtech-will-guarantee-a-healthier-future-for-all-women.html">Why investing in FemTech will guarantee a healthier future for all women</a>,” Deloitte UK, June 23, 2023.</p>
<a href="#endnote-sup-9" id="endnote-9">View in Article</a></li>
         
             <li><p>While not directly about health care or data sharing, a new study illuminates gender differences in risk-taking behavior. See: Chris Dawson, “<a href="https://neurosciencenews.com/gender-risk-taking-23431/">Daring differently: Gender differences in risk-taking behavior</a>,” Neuroscience News, June 10, 2023.</p>
<a href="#endnote-sup-10" id="endnote-10">View in Article</a></li>
         
             <li><p>Steve Alder, "<a href="https://www.hipaajournal.com/americans-mistakenly-believe-health-app-hipaa/">Majority of Americans mistakenly believe health app data is covered by HIPAA</a>," <i>The HIPAA Journal</i>, July 26, 2023.</p>
<a href="#endnote-sup-11" id="endnote-11">View in Article</a></li>
         
             <li><p>Najd Alfawzan, Markus Christen, Giovanni Spitale, and Nikola Biller-Andorno, "<a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9123546/">Privacy, data sharing, and data security policies of women’s mHealth apps: Scoping review and content analysis</a>," <i>JMIR Mhealth Uhealth</i>, May 6, 2022.</p>
<a href="#endnote-sup-12" id="endnote-12">View in Article</a></li>
         
             <li><p>Rina Torchinsky, "<a href="https://www.npr.org/2022/05/10/1097482967/roe-v-wade-supreme-court-abortion-period-apps">How period tracking apps and data privacy fit into a post-Roe v. Wade climate</a>," <i>NPR</i>, June 24, 2022; Chandra Steele, "<a href="https://www.pcmag.com/news/people-are-rightly-concerned-about-data-privacy-for-womens-health-apps">People are (rightly) concerned about data privacy for women's health apps</a>," <i>PCMag</i>, February 22, 2023.</p>
<a href="#endnote-sup-13" id="endnote-13">View in Article</a></li>
         
             <li><p>Kashmir Hill, "<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/06/30/technology/period-tracker-privacy-abortion.html">Deleting your period tracker won't protect you</a>," <i>The New York Times</i>, June 30, 2022.</p>
<a href="#endnote-sup-14" id="endnote-14">View in Article</a></li>
         
             <li><p>Sheryl Jacobson and Jen Radin,"<a href="https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/blog/health-care-blog/2023/can-femtech-help-bridge-a-gender-equity-gap-in-health-care.html">Can FemTech help bridge a gender-equity gap in health care?</a>"; Karen Taylor, "<a href="https://blogs.deloitte.co.uk/health/2023/06/celebrating-the-nhs-at-75-why-investing-in-femtech-will-guarantee-a-healthier-future-for-all-women.html">Why investing in FemTech will guarantee a healthier future for all women</a>.”</p>
<a href="#endnote-sup-15" id="endnote-15">View in Article</a></li>
        </ol>

    function getCookie(name) 
    {
        var dc = document.cookie;
        var prefix = name + "=";
        var begin = dc.indexOf("; " + prefix);
        if (begin == -1) {
            begin = dc.indexOf(prefix);
            if (begin != 0) return null;
        }
        else
        {
            begin += 2;
            var end = document.cookie.indexOf(";", begin);
            if (end == -1) {
                end = dc.length;
            }
        }
        return unescape(dc.substring(begin + prefix.length, end));
    }
